abstract:
Little has been done in the study of these intriguing questions, and I do not wish to give the impression that any extensive
set of ideas exists that could be called a "theory." What is quite surprising, as far as the histories of science and philosophy
are concerned, is that the major impetus for the fantastic growth of interest in brain processes, both psychological and physiological,
has come from a device, a machine, the digital computer. In dealing with a human being and a human society, we enjoy the luxury
of being irrational, illogical, inconsistent, and incomplete, and yet of coping. In operating a computer, we must meet the
rigorous requirements for detailed instructions and absolute precision. If we understood the ability of the human mind to
make effective decisions when confronted by complexity, uncertainty, and irrationality then we could use computers a million
times more effectively than we do. Recognition of this fact has been a motivation for the spurt of research in the field of
neurophysiology.
